text: the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of this new
shushu project ignore grief this is the
newest full-length LP from experimental
music veterans shushu who are always
cooking up something interesting daring
and conceptual especially in this leg of
their career whether it's Nina Simone
covers or reimagining the Twin Peaks
soundtrack one of their snappiest
records and years forget one of their
most harrowing records in years a girl
with basket of fruit there was also that
series of Duets on their last project oh
no point is you never really know what
you're going to get on a new album from
shushu which is as true as ever on their
13th full-length LP here because not
only does this new record feature a lot
more vocals from long time member and
multi-instrumentalist Angela but shushu
has also been officially joined This
Time Around by drummer David Kendrick
who's known for playing with new wave
and all pop weirdos like Devo and Sparks
but don't let that trick you into
thinking that we're in for something
light or tongue-in-cheek this time
around because I think ignore grief is
an attempt at possibly the darkest
shushu record thus far which might seem
kind of confusing given that the band
just put out girl with basket but I
would characterize that album more as
like a chaotic anxiety-inducing mental
breakdown whereas ignore grief here I
think is just a Showcase of pure horror
Horrors that in many cases are all too
common and all too real whether that be
sex trafficking drug addiction murder
abuse and much more which are all
explored with some of the grimmest
instrumental palettes of any shushu
record swinging back and forth between
the kind of harsh post-industrial noise
that they've been known to indulge in
from time to time two frightening and
dissonant passages of orchestral
instrumentation that'll make the hair on
your neck stand up the sound of this
thing is Bleak it's uncompromising but
surprisingly the track list runs in a
pretty cut and dry fashion with 10 song
is averaging at about a length of four
minutes the sound of these tracks is
certainly out there but the band planned
them out to be a pretty straightforward
much of the time also the song titles
are quite something the real chaos
Cha-cha-cha 666 photos of nothing
Pahrump as well as Dracula parrot Moon
moth just to name a few so yeah those
are something and the instrumentation on
these tracks is even more something
plenty of bone chilling moments to be
had there's border Factory whose
mechanical drums clangs bangs and
whaling synthesizers sound like an
assembly line where they make nightmares
Angela's muttered spoken word passages
on the track sound like a depressed
floor manager's loudspeaker
announcements being drowned out by the
chaos I just wish it developed more
across the length of the track I don't
know hit a climax or something at the
end rather than just sort of fizzling
out there's also the opener whose rigid
percussion hits squeaks hits of rumbling
bass and noise and piano all feel like
I'm stuck in Satan's cuckoo clock once
again though the ending is sort of
abrupt and Angela's vocal passages as
chilling as they are often get smothered
in the mix I do think her vocals shine a
bit more though on the tracks maybe baby
as well as escarid a little Richard and
they're the better for it especially on
the latter where her repeated mantras of
ignore grief ignore grief ignore grief
come from a place of genuine desperation
so you have tracks like these that go in
more of a noise and Industrial direction
that are pretty good then there are
others that uh feel like an experimental
take on the kind of campy Sound Stage
instrumentation you would get out of an
old Hollywood horror film like 666
photos of nothing whose instrumental I
think runs a little thin sometimes plus
there are parts of this track that feel
like they're just trying too hard to be
freakish and as a result of that it kind
of takes away from the genuinely dark
topics being addressed in the lyrics
like when you have these sour piano
chords being hit at random toward the
very end of the song There's a similar
combo of era and Aesthetics being pulled
from drum on deeper Cuts Like tarsier
tarsier tarsi or tarsier but this track
goes over slightly better Jamie Stewart
hits some much more chilling and
hard-hitting vocal passages on the track
the instrumental generally is more
cohesive with this continuously twisted
and creepy series of droning chord
progressions but then moving on to the
last leg of this project the album's
general issues and problems kind of
continue onto here too time and time
again the band conjures these
incomparably dark instrumental palettes
orbiting around really twisted subject
matters which in concept is fine but the
progressions often stagnate after a
while especially with such Meandering
vocal performances and nowhere is this
more apparent than on the 8 Minute
closer for M which does start strong
with some bone crushingly harsh passages
of noise and bass all culminating but a
great deal of this song's first leg is
spent impatiently shifting from idea to
idea preventing any real development
from happening and then we eventually
progress to a point where at the very
end we're kind of riding this uh grown
until it ascends into a high-pitched
whale and we're essentially out of here
which uh I don't know was really
anything then edge of my seat frankly
sadly I'm not really crazy about this
shushu record there were Pockets there
were moments there were tracks uh whose
darkness really did cut deep the content
of the lyrics as well is uncompromising
and uh for sure will be shocking and
triggering to some so a tread lightly I
would say and again this is fine shushu
has addressed very dark subject matters
in their music before and shishu has
made very harsh and terrifying music
before but in this instance it feels
like they're pushing those elements to
such an extreme that they're kind of
foregoing the other elements that they
are usually so good at showcasing and
focusing on when it comes to songwriting
song structuring Melody and a host of
other things too so while I think this
record at the end of the day does stand
out in the group's discography it's not
necessarily for the best of reason nor
do I find many of the individual songs
on this LP to be all that memorable
either feeling a light to decent six on
this one transition have you given this
